title: Retro Electric Razors
description: Remember the buzz of your first electric shaver? Test your grooming gadget knowledge

questions.question: Which company, founded by Jacob Schick, introduced the first practical electric dry shaver in 1931?
What brand of electric shaver became famous for its rotating triple-head design introduced in the 1960s?
What classic Norelco Christmas TV commercial showed Santa Claus doing what?
options: Riding across the snow on a Norelco shaver
Using a shaver as a sled

questions.question: What type of shaving head design did Remington shavers typically use, unlike the rotary heads of Norelco?
What German brand, known for its clean Bauhaus-inspired design, produced premium electric shavers starting in the 1950s?
What traditional shaving tool, consisting of a brush and a cup of soap, was commonly replaced by electric razors?
What feature did many bathroom medicine cabinets have specifically designed for electric shavers?
What popular aftershave brand, featured in TV commercials where a man slapped it on and exclaimed, was a staple of men's grooming?
What was the name of Gillette's popular safety razor that used disposable double-edged blades?
What Remington advertising slogan, delivered by company owner Victor Kiam, became famous in the 1980s?
options: 'I liked it so much, I bought the company'

questions.question: What product, applied to the face before using an electric razor, was said to help the shaver glide more smoothly?
What was a common gift given to teenage boys as a rite of passage when they started needing to shave?
options: A shaving kit with a safety razor

questions.question: What ladies' grooming appliance, often pink or pastel colored, was the female equivalent of the men's electric shaver?
options: A Lady Remington or Lady Norelco shaver

questions.question: What small brush, included with most electric shavers, was used for regular maintenance and cleaning?
options: A cleaning brush for removing whisker dust

questions.question: What type of rechargeable battery technology, common in cordless shavers of the 1970s and 1980s, was eventually replaced by lithium-ion?
